That is not true - you have either dual core CPU or 4-core without hyperthreading if you get only 1 thread for decoding. The idea here is to limit the number of OpenMP threads to the number of physical cores - 1, so that the scheduler is not starved for resources, even if preprocess_threads variable is higher than that. We could lift that restriction and rely on user to provide the option that makes sense.
What's wrong with the original implementation?

The logic behind the construct in the Makefile is that use of lapack is switched off if we do not find the library at some standard locations and if we find it there, then it is also ensured that the linker finds it. This is the case for the prior existing cases as /lib and /usr/lib are always in the search path of the linker. 
For /usr/lib64, I don't know whether this always would be in the linker search path. So I think it would be better to ensure that if we do find lapack not on the standard paths /lib/,  usr/lib and the special USE_LAPACK_PATH, but we find it in /usr/lib64, then we ensure explicitly that we put /usr/lib64 also into the linker search path. This way it will never happen that we get a final linker error at the end.
What was the resolution?

This is still a useful feature request. Just because nothing has happened on this for 90 days didn't change that.

Size of library can vary a lot based on the config used to make, so it would be helpful to paste your complete build config here.

Regarding whether there's any missed dependencies, the easiest way to check whether your libmxnet is linked against the appropriate libraries is to run
```bash
readelf -d libmxnet.so
```
To you think the changes to lstm and gru cells could be transposed into the ones in rnn.graph? Since the recent review of the RNN API, the lstm.R and gru.R are no longer used.

Thinking a bit more about this, I am a bit confused about why there is any synchronisation at all. I'm really new to mxnet, so I might be missing something, but shouldn't the engine be able to tell if there are any outstanding operations at all? And if not, couldn't it just skip the `ThreadedVar::WaitForVar` call entirely? If there is nothing that might want to change *any* variable, then that variable in particular should be fine, right? My guess would be that this is the case most of the time when executing things synchronously.

The perl cpu/gpu tests passed. Could you please merge it at your convenience, thanks.
There was a bug in the code resolved by adding `NDArray:: WaitAll()` after the call to `GetData()`.

BTW there's an [example](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/5235bb3a60805c4a9c5e9e5c9afa90af0a8aa54d/example/sparse/linear_classification.py) for sparse linear regression on cpu using the sparse ndarray feature in MXNet using the module API
You are not using the out_grad in the backward() function, in other words, you are not following chain rule and thus creating whatever gradient you want. The cutomOp itself act as a loss layer.

The computation graph is a graph, not stacks,  I don't think there's a general enough condition to determine which layer should be freeze or not unless the network has no branch.
Tl;DR, you have to specify layers by their names.

Mac OSX python users have the option to use pre-built pip packages now. The package names are `mxnet` and `mxnet-mkl`. We also offer nightly builds as beta pre-release, available through pip's `--pre` switch. Starting from 0.11.0, the pip packages depend on opencv 3.3. Though a hack is needed to use the compatible header in imgcodecs.

Feel free to ping me to reopen if there's still issue in building OSX version.
We have a super resolution example now in Gluon interface. https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/example/gluon/super_resolution.py

We now provide OSX pre-built pip packages, which has opencv support. See instructions here: https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/get_started/install.html

We have several RNN APIs now so there really is not need to implement your own any more:

[Gluon LSTM layer](https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/gluon.html?highlight=rnn#mxnet.gluon.rnn.LSTM) and [Gluon LSTM cell](https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/gluon.html?highlight=rnn#mxnet.gluon.rnn.LSTMCell), and [examples](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/gluon/word_language_model)
[Symbol RNN LSTMCell](https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/rnn.html?highlight=rnn#mxnet.rnn.LSTMCell) and [examples](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/rnn)
Why are we hosting our own jquery? They have their own CDN and has a minified version instead of the full version, which is good for loading time.
The example works fine.
@xmyqsh Can you check with the torch implementation? If we consider that the outside pixels are all zero, the current implementation should be correct.

@sxjscience 
yeah, the implementation in torch is also assumed the outside pixels is zero.
@xmyqsh So the current implementation should be consistent with torch's implementation.

@piiswrong: the addition of a test for ELU is causing failures in `test_operator.test_broadcast_binary_op`:
```
Items are not equal:
Error 14.595687 exceeds tolerance rtol=0.010000, atol=0.001000.  Location of maximum error:(0, 0, 4), a=0.014596, b=0.000000
 NUMERICAL_a: array([[[ 1.72120333,  1.26115978,  1.4104917 ,  1.06704044,  0.01459569]],

       [[ 0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        ,  0.44905394]],...
 BACKWARD_a: array([[[ 1.72122073,  1.26117206,  1.41049075,  1.06703949,  0.        ]],

       [[ 0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        ,  0.4490537 ]],...
```
This PR makes no changes to any dependencies of this test, so the only explanation is that different random numbers are used, and this is causing a violation of the tolerance bound.

What should I do? (I could hack it and put the ELU test after the broadcast_binary_op test, or change the tolerance of this test)

For Debian based distributions it should be in the linker search path already as it's the default location for 64bit libraries: https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/LibraryPathOverview

On Amazon Linux (RHEL based) it seems to also be on the path:
```bash
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-14-78 ~]$ gcc -Xlinker -v
collect2 version 4.8.3 20140911 (Red Hat 4.8.3-9)
/usr/bin/ld --build-id --no-add-needed --eh-frame-hdr --hash-style=gnu -m elf_x86_64 -dynamic-linker /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/../../../../lib64/crt1.o /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/../../../../lib64/crti.o /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/crtbegin.o -L/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3 -L/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/../../../../lib64 -L/lib/../lib64 -L/usr/lib/../lib64 -L/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/../../.. -v -lgcc --as-needed -lgcc_s --no-as-needed -lc -lgcc --as-needed -lgcc_s --no-as-needed /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/crtend.o /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-amazon-linux/4.8.3/../../../../lib64/crtn.o
GNU ld version 2.23.52.0.1-55.65.amzn1 20130226
```

Just thinking a little more about what we're doing here and, as a developer, I find this behaviour quite counter-intuitive.  Currently I have the LAPACK flag turned on in the build configuration, I build a project successfully, and later at runtime I notice that in fact LAPACK wasn't linked.  I then have to search through the source for references to the LAPACK variable to find that it is silently turned off without logging in the Makefile.  This seems to be the case with LAPACK but with no other linked library, and I'm not sure what the cause for the inconsistent behaviour is here.  I would actually prefer to get a linker error so that I know something is wrong.
As we've discussed, it builds on osx for cpu, but not gpu. I'm working on maven deploy currently. The gpu support for osx is under relatively low priority. I'll make a roadmap soon.

I would remove all these nested checks and let the linker fail. I don't see that this is a standard pattern to check for all possible locations if the library is present. Usually people rely on configure to check for libraries and not the makefile, or defer to a better build system like CMake to detect the lib.

but for the most network architectures, they could have many branches, but only one torso. we just need to specify the layer name which is in the torso, then the bottom  layers behind it could be freezed.

Is it possible that the smaller version of the package is jit'ing CUDA code for your device as part of your performance measurement?  If you run the same code twice is the second run faster?  If you run on CPU is there a large difference between 0.95 and .11?  Does the size of your nvidia cache folder change between runs?

The goal of these dockerfiles is not to replace CI but to create multi-arch binary artifacts. Also when you use the docker build with these kind of dockerfile you get the benefit of command caching. But I get your point with regards environment vs execution.

Maybe we need  an attribute, like the one in memonger, for each operator to determine if bp is necessary. We should be able to derive if the bp is needed. Also some cases exist that bp is required but param updates are not wanted.

The word language model is intended to be a simple example, not a SOTA solution. I'm not sure we should keep adding more stuff to it.

Since the documentation was not clear to indhub@, is there an opportunity here to clarify/improve the API documentation? What is we update the document to say: 
from: 
global_pool (boolean, optional, default=False) – Ignore kernel size, do global pooling based on current input feature map.
to: (something like this)
global_pool (boolean, optional, default=False) – Ignore kernel size, but the kernel must be specified to determine the shape of the stride and whether the Pooling Operation is 1d or 2d or 3d based on the shape of the kernel. Do global pooling based on current input feature map.
The list has been taken from http://incubator.apache.org/projects/mxnet.html
